Macron reappoints Lecornu, who had resigned on Monday, as prime minister
Subhead: Sébastien Lecornu had resigned as prime minister hours after forming his cabinet. He then led talks during the week, saying he believed there was still a way forward for passing a budget without holding snap elections.

Faced with a looming gasoline shortage, California's governor backs off oil companies
Subhead: Gavin Newsom, who only a year ago denounced the companies' 'lies' and 'greed,' has made a U-turn − much to the dismay of environmentalists.

Title: 'In the United States, Congress no longer exists as a counterbalance'
Subhead: In an op-ed for Le Monde, researcher Hugo Toudic reflects on the recent Senate hearing of US Attorney General Pam Bondi.

Title: Paris's remarkable fashion week masks the luxury industry's headlong rush
Subhead: By reigniting the dream machine, the so-called 'fashion week of the century' has signaled the rise of a new generation of designers − but without revealing anything about the intentions of the leaders of luxury conglomerates.

Title: Tiago Rodrigues: 'The Avignon Festival does not have the production resources it deserves'
Subhead: Portuguese theater director Tiago Rodrigues, 48, has been reappointed as director of the Avignon Festival until 2030. Reflecting on his achievements and looking ahead, the artist takes stock of the French theater festival.

Matthieu Blazy: 'Just because Karl was a legend does not mean that everyone who designs for Chanel has to be one too'
Subhead: The anticipation was overwhelming. But on Monday, the first show by Chanel's new artistic director under the glass roof of the Grand Palais lived up to all expectations. With his impeccable CV and strong personality, the 41-year-old designer has written the first page of a new chapter for the fashion house. His mission? To usher it into a new era without losing its soul.

Title: A spa day at home, an erotic utopia to explore
Subhead: What if sex could be as soothing and wellness-oriented as a day at the spa? Maïa Mazaurette, a columnist for Le Monde, explores this dreamy scenario.

Title: Robert Badinter's secret face-to-face with the guillotine, in four unseen pictures
Subhead: Ahead of Robert Badinter's induction into France's Panthéon, one of his former aides decided to reveal photos he took in 1981. They show the man who championed the abolition of the death penalty staring down his sworn enemy, the guillotine.
